61ST YEAR

Kennan Backs Adlai SC Considering Resolutions
On H-Bomb Proposal Concerning Student Conduct
by JOHN ROTHNEY and HOWARD J. WASKOW

George .F Kennan, former United States ambassador to the
Soviet Union, Wednesday night strongly endorsed Democratic
Candidate Adlai Stevenson's recent proposals to end large-scale
thermonuclear tests.
In a News-Letter interview, prior to his foreign-policy lecture on the Hopkins campus, Mr. Kennan, chief architect of the
Policy of "containment" of Soviet Russia, asserted, "I strongly
approve of Mr. Stevenson's initiative, and consider arguments
against his proposal that I have seen to this time, to be mostly
unsubstantial. I cannot understand how our government can
be so little worried about the
Psychological effects all over the
world of the H-bomb tests."
Mr. Kennan, who has been
mentioned as a possible appointee as Secretary of State
should Mr. Stevenson be elected,
declined to answer several questions on current world events,
saying, "I am an historian now
... I have no intention of reentering public service. I am a
professor and seem to like it."
However, Mr. Kennan, did permit quotation in answer to a
question asking whether the attitude of rigid hostility essential
to American security precluded
this country's taking advantages
of changes or weaknesses on the
Soviet scene. He stated, "Until
there is agreement on the major
Specific differences dividing us
and The Soviet Unidn, I think
we ought to keep our military
strength intact, but within that
framework we ought to be gratified at any signs of liberality on
the other side and ought to reciprocate them generously."
Asked whether the conduct of
foreign affairs had been removed
by its complexity from the sphere
of domestic partisan controversy, Mr. Kerman repl i.e d,
"There is not much difference
in objectives, but foreign policy
is a matter of style, like tennis,
and there are great differences in
Style of different presidents and
secretaries of state."

DSRC Should Not Approve
Unpopular Rules—Hutchins
"If the dormitory students are
against certain rulings, then it
is not right that the DSRC
(Dormitory Students Representative Council) should pass those
rulings," stated DSRC President
Bob Hutchins.
Unpopular Resolution
Questioned whether he would
yield to administrative pressure
and attempt to pass an unpopular resolution, Hutchins said he
would not. "The DSRC wants to
work with both the administration and the students; however,
we are basically a student organization and should work for the
students. If the administration
wants something of this nature
and a large majority are against
the
administration
it, then
shouldn't leave it up to us to
pass their rulings," continued
Hutchins. Re-emphasizeing, he

stated, "The DSRC wants to
work with both the administration and the students, but we
will work with the administration as representatives of the
students."
Getting Organized
Referring to the constitution
which is being drafted by a constitution committee headed by
Herb Kahler (There are no existing copies of the old DSRC constitution, presumably drafted
shortly after World War II.)
Hutchins said,"We're getting organized very well right now. We
would like to start group discussions. It is our aim to give every
resident in the dormitories a
chance to work on it if possible."
Rejected
Hutchins felt that the constitution offered to the dormitory
last year was rejected because of

its proposed trial system. "If the
committee can find something
•efinite to replace the trial system, that will be fine. The
DSRC's basic responsibility is to
protect the rights of those residing in. the dorm. We want to
talk with the students to find
out what their opinions are and
to see what should be done."
According to Hutchins, there
are no provisions being planned
to house female guests in the
dormitories. In past years, House
Four has been used for this purpose for special weekends.
Frozen Funds
Technically the Student Activities Committee has frozen the
funds of the DSRC, but said
Hutchins, "I think the SAC will
cooperate with us; they have already allowed appropriations for
the Dorm Social."

NEWS -LETTER

Stray Girls Raise Student Query

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 19, 1956

Tau Beta Pi Pledges Nine;
Owens Attends Convention
The Hopkins chapter of Tau
Beta Pi, national engineering
honor society, has pledged seven
seniors and two juniors for membership, it was announced this
week.

Greek Slate Clean
From Violations
Of Rushing Rules
With rushing entering its third
week, Bill Kolomaznik, President
of the Interfraternity Board, announced that there have been
no violations of the rushing rules.
Kolomaznik also stated that
prior to the beginning of rushing this year, the IFB sent a letter to the residents of the neighborhood in which the fraternity
houses are located asking them
to report all disturbances to the
Vigilante Committee. To date,
the Vigilantes have received no
calls.

The nine- pledges are: George
Fischer, Mel Frome, Steve Kacala, Jim Anderson, Dick Crutch,
field, Charles Schrodel, Kevin
Kries, Stan Middleman and Gil
Decker. The latter two are juniors.
To be eligible for membership
in Tau Beta Pi, a junior must
stand in the top ' eighth of his
class, a senior in the top fifth.
Besides this, selection is based
on "integrity, breadth of interest both inside and outside of
engineering, adaptability and
unselfish activity."
At their first pledge meeting
on Tuesday afternoon, the nine
prospective members were each
told to write an essay on either
of two topics: "An Engineer's
Civic Responsibility" or "The
Student Engineer as a Campus
Citizen." The best essay of the
group will be submitted to a
national contest.
As their project they must distribute questionnaires to the engineering class and then compile
a critique from this survey. Two
more pledge meetings will be
held, October 23 and 30.
The National Convention of
Tau Beta Pi was held at the
University of Kansas on October 10-13. Tom Owens, delegate
from the local chapter, served
on an activities panel and spoke
to the convention concerning
society projects.

between the United States, and
the Communist power will probably be decided is in the area
of those countries who are neither in their orbit or ours." Later
in the lecture, he suggested. that
to be successful in this area "we
may have to take under tighter
control the processes of our own
participation in international
trade. ... There .may be marginal areas in which limits would
have to be placed on private
American industry and the government may have to go into the
same areas on its own hook (as
a trader)."

Americans have tended to draw
an analogy from the personal
freedom of individual American
citizens to the international
freedom of nations. Since American personal freedom was dependent on exact legal equality,
Mr. Kennan continued, Americans expected nations to be
equated under international law.
Therefore, the "crazy-quilt" of
Europe-the result of political,
historical, and geographical differences was "contrary, to the
American concept of "international egalitarianism."

The problems to be met in
these areas have arisen, Mr. Kennan felt, for three reasons: first,
"We are promoting the farmingout (among many sovereignties)
of the control of the sources of
industrial raw materials"; second, "We continue to concede
the power of (those) sovereignties to concede or deny resources
at will"; third, "We are permitting technological trends in our
society (a growing need for resources from foreign nations) to
make the situation more acute."
The "situation" needing correction, Mr. Kennan said, is the
resultant disparity between
"what resources we demand and
what we can get."

Arising in the last 50 years,
Mr. Kennan pointed out, partly
as a result of American promotion of the sovereignty concept,
have been 50 new nations, many
of them "with a shallow experience with the responsibilities of
sovereignty." Stipulating the importance of common recognition
of responsibility between interdependent nations, the lecturer
said, "I shudder to think that we
are permitting ourselves to be-

come dependent on others for
such important commodities as
iron ore and oil without making
known to ourselves and the
others our ... responsibilities. If
ever we find ourselves suddenly
denied by the outside world' a
necessity to our life, I wouldn't
want to vouch for our own behavior."
Accentuating the problem of
resources, Mr. Kennan suggested, is the "growing dependance
of our country on sources of raw
materials beyond our borders" as
the result of "the progressive exhaustion of certain resources," an
unexpectedly large population
growth bringing consumption
which has outstripped technological advancements. "We belong," he said, "to the more
fragile part of international society."

CHARLES I. SMITH,JR., received his B.S. Ch.E.
from V.P.I. in 1943, served in the Navy as an
engineer officer, and joined Du Pont's Engineering Department in 1946. Since then, he has advanced steadily through a number of interesting
assignments at various Du Pont plants. He was
recently promoted to manager of the Technical
Section of Du Pont's Pigments Department.

WATCH "DU PONT CAVALCADE THEATER" ON TV

They have an almost endless variety of interesting
problems to face, George. As a student of metallurgy,
you know that about two-thirds of all known chemical
elements are metals. Many of them are revealing valuable new applications, when highly purified on a commercial scale. Du Pont is greatly interested in several
metallic and semi-metallic elements.
My own experience at Du Pont ranges from work
on titanium pigments,to metallic titanium production,
and to the ultra-pure silicon used in transistors. You
can appreciate some ofour metallurgical problems when
I point out that impurities in transistor silicon have to
be below one part in 100 million. That's equivalent to
one pound of impurities distributed through a train of
ore cars twenty miles long!
Some of our metallurgists carry out fundamental
research on new metals, and,in the development stage,
they frequently operate pilot plantsfor producing them.
Other metallurgists study problems relating to engineering materials used in construction, carry out research on intergranular corrosion,or investigate fatigue
relationships encountered in dynamic, high-pressure
operations.
You'll find many challenging opportunities in every
phase of metallurgy at Du Pont, George.

by JOHN ROTHNEY and HOWARD J. WASKOW

George .F Kennan, former United States ambassador to the
Soviet Union, Wednesday night strongly endorsed Democratic
Candidate Adlai Stevenson's recent proposals to end large-scale
thermonuclear tests.
In a News-Letter interview, prior to his foreign-policy lecture on the Hopkins campus, Mr. Kennan, chief architect of the
Policy of "containment" of Soviet Russia, asserted, "I strongly
approve of Mr. Stevenson's initiative, and consider arguments
against his proposal that I have seen to this time, to be mostly
unsubstantial. I cannot understand how our government can
be so little worried about the
Psychological effects all over the
world of the H-bomb tests."
Mr. Kennan, who has been
mentioned as a possible appointee as Secretary of State
should Mr. Stevenson be elected,
declined to answer several questions on current world events,
saying, "I am an historian now
... I have no intention of reentering public service. I am a
professor and seem to like it."
However, Mr. Kennan, did permit quotation in answer to a
question asking whether the attitude of rigid hostility essential
to American security precluded
this country's taking advantages
of changes or weaknesses on the
Soviet scene. He stated, "Until
there is agreement on the major
Specific differences dividing us
and The Soviet Unidn, I think
we ought to keep our military
strength intact, but within that
framework we ought to be gratified at any signs of liberality on
the other side and ought to reciprocate them generously."
Asked whether the conduct of
foreign affairs had been removed
by its complexity from the sphere
of domestic partisan controversy, Mr. Kerman repl i.e d,
"There is not much difference
in objectives, but foreign policy
is a matter of style, like tennis,
and there are great differences in
Style of different presidents and
secretaries of state."

Unpopular Rules—Hutchins
"If the dormitory students are
against certain rulings, then it
is not right that the DSRC
(Dormitory Students Representative Council) should pass those
rulings," stated DSRC President
Bob Hutchins.
Unpopular Resolution
Questioned whether he would
yield to administrative pressure
and attempt to pass an unpopular resolution, Hutchins said he
would not. "The DSRC wants to
work with both the administration and the students; however,
we are basically a student organization and should work for the
students. If the administration
wants something of this nature
and a large majority are against
the
administration
it, then
shouldn't leave it up to us to
pass their rulings," continued
Hutchins. Re-emphasizeing, he

stated, "The DSRC wants to
work with both the administration and the students, but we
will work with the administration as representatives of the
students."
Getting Organized
Referring to the constitution
which is being drafted by a constitution committee headed by
Herb Kahler (There are no existing copies of the old DSRC constitution, presumably drafted
shortly after World War II.)
Hutchins said,"We're getting organized very well right now. We
would like to start group discussions. It is our aim to give every
resident in the dormitories a
chance to work on it if possible."
Rejected
Hutchins felt that the constitution offered to the dormitory
last year was rejected because of

its proposed trial system. "If the
committee can find something
•efinite to replace the trial system, that will be fine. The
DSRC's basic responsibility is to
protect the rights of those residing in. the dorm. We want to
talk with the students to find
out what their opinions are and
to see what should be done."
According to Hutchins, there
are no provisions being planned
to house female guests in the
dormitories. In past years, House
Four has been used for this purpose for special weekends.
Frozen Funds
Technically the Student Activities Committee has frozen the
funds of the DSRC, but said
Hutchins, "I think the SAC will
cooperate with us; they have already allowed appropriations for
the Dorm Social."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 19, 1956

Tau Beta Pi Pledges Nine;
Owens Attends Convention
The Hopkins chapter of Tau
Beta Pi, national engineering
honor society, has pledged seven
seniors and two juniors for membership, it was announced this
week.

Greek Slate Clean
From Violations
Of Rushing Rules
With rushing entering its third
week, Bill Kolomaznik, President
of the Interfraternity Board, announced that there have been
no violations of the rushing rules.
Kolomaznik also stated that
prior to the beginning of rushing this year, the IFB sent a letter to the residents of the neighborhood in which the fraternity
houses are located asking them
to report all disturbances to the
Vigilante Committee. To date,
the Vigilantes have received no
calls.

The nine- pledges are: George
Fischer, Mel Frome, Steve Kacala, Jim Anderson, Dick Crutch,
field, Charles Schrodel, Kevin
Kries, Stan Middleman and Gil
Decker. The latter two are juniors.
To be eligible for membership
in Tau Beta Pi, a junior must
stand in the top ' eighth of his
class, a senior in the top fifth.
Besides this, selection is based
on "integrity, breadth of interest both inside and outside of
engineering, adaptability and
unselfish activity."
At their first pledge meeting
on Tuesday afternoon, the nine
prospective members were each
told to write an essay on either
of two topics: "An Engineer's
Civic Responsibility" or "The
Student Engineer as a Campus
Citizen." The best essay of the
group will be submitted to a
national contest.
As their project they must distribute questionnaires to the engineering class and then compile
a critique from this survey. Two
more pledge meetings will be
held, October 23 and 30.
The National Convention of
Tau Beta Pi was held at the
University of Kansas on October 10-13. Tom Owens, delegate
from the local chapter, served
on an activities panel and spoke
to the convention concerning
society projects.

Kennan En orses Proposal

(Continued from Page 1)
between the United States, and
the Communist power will probably be decided is in the area
of those countries who are neither in their orbit or ours." Later
in the lecture, he suggested. that
to be successful in this area "we
may have to take under tighter
control the processes of our own
participation in international
trade. ... There .may be marginal areas in which limits would
have to be placed on private
American industry and the government may have to go into the
same areas on its own hook (as
a trader)."

Americans have tended to draw
an analogy from the personal
freedom of individual American
citizens to the international
freedom of nations. Since American personal freedom was dependent on exact legal equality,
Mr. Kennan continued, Americans expected nations to be
equated under international law.
Therefore, the "crazy-quilt" of
Europe-the result of political,
historical, and geographical differences was "contrary, to the
American concept of "international egalitarianism."

The problems to be met in
these areas have arisen, Mr. Kennan felt, for three reasons: first,
"We are promoting the farmingout (among many sovereignties)
of the control of the sources of
industrial raw materials"; second, "We continue to concede
the power of (those) sovereignties to concede or deny resources
at will"; third, "We are permitting technological trends in our
society (a growing need for resources from foreign nations) to
make the situation more acute."
The "situation" needing correction, Mr. Kennan said, is the
resultant disparity between
"what resources we demand and
what we can get."

Arising in the last 50 years,
Mr. Kennan pointed out, partly
as a result of American promotion of the sovereignty concept,
have been 50 new nations, many
of them "with a shallow experience with the responsibilities of
sovereignty." Stipulating the importance of common recognition
of responsibility between interdependent nations, the lecturer
said, "I shudder to think that we
are permitting ourselves to be-

come dependent on others for
such important commodities as
iron ore and oil without making
known to ourselves and the
others our ... responsibilities. If
ever we find ourselves suddenly
denied by the outside world' a
necessity to our life, I wouldn't
want to vouch for our own behavior."
Accentuating the problem of
resources, Mr. Kennan suggested, is the "growing dependance
of our country on sources of raw
materials beyond our borders" as
the result of "the progressive exhaustion of certain resources," an
unexpectedly large population
growth bringing consumption
which has outstripped technological advancements. "We belong," he said, "to the more
fragile part of international society."

CHARLES I. SMITH,JR., received his B.S. Ch.E.
from V.P.I. in 1943, served in the Navy as an
engineer officer, and joined Du Pont's Engineering Department in 1946. Since then, he has advanced steadily through a number of interesting
assignments at various Du Pont plants. He was
recently promoted to manager of the Technical
Section of Du Pont's Pigments Department.

Metallurgists and Metallurgical Engineers
can find some of Charlie Smith's challenging
new problems described in "Engineers at

WATCH "DU PONT CAVALCADE THEATER" ON TV

They have an almost endless variety of interesting
problems to face, George. As a student of metallurgy,
you know that about two-thirds of all known chemical
elements are metals. Many of them are revealing valuable new applications, when highly purified on a commercial scale. Du Pont is greatly interested in several
metallic and semi-metallic elements.
My own experience at Du Pont ranges from work
on titanium pigments,to metallic titanium production,
and to the ultra-pure silicon used in transistors. You
can appreciate some ofour metallurgical problems when
I point out that impurities in transistor silicon have to
be below one part in 100 million. That's equivalent to
one pound of impurities distributed through a train of
ore cars twenty miles long!
Some of our metallurgists carry out fundamental
research on new metals, and,in the development stage,
they frequently operate pilot plantsfor producing them.
Other metallurgists study problems relating to engineering materials used in construction, carry out research on intergranular corrosion,or investigate fatigue
relationships encountered in dynamic, high-pressure
operations.
You'll find many challenging opportunities in every
phase of metallurgy at Du Pont, George.
